The oldest area of the town is known as [De Wallen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Wallen "De Wallen") (English: "The Quays"). It lies to the east of Damrak and contains the city's famous red-light district. To the south of De Wallen is the old Jewish quarter of Waterlooplein.

The medieval and colonial age [canals of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), known as _grachten_, embraces the heart of the city where homes have interesting gables. Beyond the Grachtengordel are the former working-class areas of [Jordaan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") and de Pijp. The [Museumplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") with the city's major museums, the [Vondelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"), a 19th-century park named after the Dutch writer [Joost van den Vondel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joost_van_den_Vondel "Joost van den Vondel"), as well as the [Plantage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plantage_(Amsterdam) "Plantage (Amsterdam)") neighbourhood, with the [zoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natura_Artis_Magistra "Natura Artis Magistra"), are also located outside the Grachtengordel.

Several parts of the city and the surrounding urban area are [polders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polder "Polder"). This can be recognised by the suffix _\-meer_ which means _lake_, as in [Aalsmeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aalsmeer "Aalsmeer"), [Bijlmermeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bijlmermeer "Bijlmermeer"), [Haarlemmermeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haarlemmermeer "Haarlemmermeer") and [Watergraafsmeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watergraafsmeer "Watergraafsmeer").

### Canals\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Canals")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg/220px-Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Town_Houses_on_Canal_in_Amsterdam_-_Nov_1977.jpg)

The Amsterdam canal system is the result of conscious [city planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning").<sup id="cite_ref-canals_154-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-canals-154">[154]</a></sup> In the early 17th century, when immigration was at a peak, a comprehensive plan was developed that was based on four concentric half-circles of canals with their ends emerging at the [IJ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") bay. Known as the [Grachtengordel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grachtengordel "Grachtengordel"), three of the canals were mostly for residential development: the Herengracht (where "Heren" refers to _Heren Regeerders van de stad Amsterdam_, ruling lords of Amsterdam, whilst _[gracht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gracht "Gracht")_ means canal, so that the name can be roughly translated as "Canal of the Lords"), Keizersgracht (Emperor's Canal) and Prinsengracht (Prince's Canal).<sup id="cite_ref-155"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> The fourth and outermost canal is the [Singelgracht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singelgracht "Singelgracht"), which is often not mentioned on maps because it is a collective name for all canals in the outer ring. The Singelgracht should not be confused with the oldest and innermost canal, the [Singel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singel "Singel").

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Herengracht-december-2.jpg/220px-Herengracht-december-2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Herengracht-december-2.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg/220px-Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Prinsengracht_towads_Lekkeresluis_from_Bridge_Prinsenstraat_2016-09-12.jpg)

The canals served for defense, [water management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_resource_management "Water resource management") and transport. The defenses took the form of a moat and [earthen dikes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earthworks_(engineering) "Earthworks (engineering)"), with gates at transit points, but otherwise no masonry [superstructures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superstructure "Superstructure").<sup id="cite_ref-156"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The original plans have been lost, so historians, such as Ed Taverne, need to speculate on the original intentions: it is thought that the considerations of the layout were purely practical and defensive rather than ornamental.<sup id="cite_ref-157"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>

Construction started in 1613 and proceeded from west to east, across the breadth of the layout, like a gigantic [windshield wiper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windscreen_wiper "Windscreen wiper") as the historian [Geert Mak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geert_Mak "Geert Mak") calls it – and not from the centre outwards, as a popular myth has it. The canal construction in the southern sector was completed by 1656. Subsequently, the construction of residential buildings proceeded slowly. The eastern part of the concentric canal plan, covering the area between the Amstel river and the IJ bay, has never been implemented. In the following centuries, the land was used for parks, senior citizens' homes, theatres, other public facilities, and waterways without much planning.<sup id="cite_ref-158"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Over the years, several canals have been filled in, becoming streets or squares, such as the [Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nieuwezijds_Voorburgwal "Nieuwezijds Voorburgwal") and the [Spui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spui_(Amsterdam) "Spui (Amsterdam)").<sup id="cite_ref-filledincanals_159-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-filledincanals-159">[159]</a></sup>

### Expansion\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Expansion")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg/220px-Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Brug_127_in_de_Lijnbaansgracht_over_de_Egelantiersgracht_foto_4.jpg)

After the development of Amsterdam's canals in the 17th century, the city did not grow beyond its borders for two centuries. During the 19th century, [Samuel Sarphati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Sarphati "Samuel Sarphati") devised a plan based on the grandeur of Paris and London at that time. The plan envisaged the construction of new houses, public buildings and streets just outside the [Grachtengordel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grachtengordel_(Amsterdam) "Grachtengordel (Amsterdam)"). The main aim of the plan, however, was to improve public health. Although the plan did not expand the city, it did produce some of the largest public buildings to date, like the _Paleis voor Volksvlijt_.<sup id="cite_ref-joodsmuseum_160-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-joodsmuseum-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zgsarphati_161-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-zgsarphati-161">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jlgsarphati_162-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-jlgsarphati-162">[162]</a></sup>

Following Sarphati, civil engineers Jacobus van Niftrik and Jan Kalff designed an entire ring of 19th-century neighbourhoods surrounding the city's centre, with the city preserving the ownership of all land outside the 17th-century limit, thus firmly controlling development.<sup id="cite_ref-163"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> Most of these neighbourhoods became home to the working class.<sup id="cite_ref-oudzuid_164-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-oudzuid-164">[164]</a></sup>

In response to overcrowding, two plans were designed at the beginning of the 20th century which were very different from anything Amsterdam had ever seen before: _Plan Zuid_ (designed by the architect [Berlage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hendrik_Petrus_Berlage "Hendrik Petrus Berlage")) and _West_. These plans involved the development of new neighbourhoods consisting of housing blocks for all social classes.<sup id="cite_ref-archiefberlage_165-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-archiefberlage-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bmzberlage_166-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-bmzberlage-166">[166]</a></sup>

After the Second World War, large new neighbourhoods were built in the western, southeastern, and northern parts of the city. These new neighbourhoods were built to relieve the city's shortage of living space and give people affordable houses with modern conveniences. The neighbourhoods consisted mainly of large housing blocks located among green spaces, connected to wide roads, making the neighbourhoods easily accessible by [motor car](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car "Car"). The western suburbs which were built in that period are collectively called the Westelijke Tuinsteden. The area to the southeast of the city built during the same period is known as the Bijlmer.<sup id="cite_ref-bijlmer_167-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-bijlmer-167">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-westelijketuinsteden_168-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-westelijketuinsteden-168">[168]</a></sup>

### Architecture\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Architecture")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Palacio_Real%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg/220px-Palacio_Real%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Palacio_Real,_%C3%81msterdam,_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos,_2016-05-30,_DD_07-09_HDR.jpg)

Amsterdam has a rich [architectural history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_architecture "History of architecture"). The oldest building in Amsterdam is the [Oude Kerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oude_Kerk,_Amsterdam "Oude Kerk, Amsterdam") (English: Old Church), at the heart of the Wallen, consecrated in 1306.<sup id="cite_ref-Oude_Kerk_169-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Oude_Kerk-169">[169]</a></sup> The oldest wooden building is _Het Houten Huys_<sup id="cite_ref-houtenhuys_170-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-houtenhuys-170">[170]</a></sup> at the [Begijnhof](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Begijnhof,_Amsterdam "Begijnhof, Amsterdam"). It was constructed around 1425 and is one of only two existing wooden buildings. It is also one of the few examples of [Gothic architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") in Amsterdam. The oldest stone building of the Netherlands, The Moriaan is built in ['s-Hertogenbosch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%27s-Hertogenbosch "'s-Hertogenbosch").

In the 16th century, wooden buildings were razed and replaced with brick ones. During this period, many buildings were constructed in the [architectural style](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architectural_style "Architectural style") of the [Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Renaissance "The Renaissance"). Buildings of this period are very recognisable with their [stepped gable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crow-stepped_gable "Crow-stepped gable") façades, which is the common Dutch Renaissance style. Amsterdam quickly developed its own [Renaissance architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture"). These buildings were built according to the principles of the architect [Hendrick de Keyser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hendrick_de_Keyser "Hendrick de Keyser").<sup id="cite_ref-dekeyser_171-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-dekeyser-171">[171]</a></sup> One of the most striking buildings designed by Hendrick de Keyser is the [Westerkerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westerkerk "Westerkerk"). In the 17th century [baroque architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") became very popular, as it was elsewhere in Europe. This roughly coincided with Amsterdam's [Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_Golden_Age "Dutch Golden Age"). The leading architects of this style in Amsterdam were [Jacob van Campen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_van_Campen "Jacob van Campen"), [Philips Vingboons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philips_Vingboons "Philips Vingboons") and [Daniel Stalpaert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dani%C3%ABl_Stalpaert "Daniël Stalpaert").<sup id="cite_ref-holclass_172-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-holclass-172">[172]</a></sup>

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/BegijnhofAmsterdamNederlandPanorama.jpg/220px-BegijnhofAmsterdamNederlandPanorama.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BegijnhofAmsterdamNederlandPanorama.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%C3%96ffentliche_Bibliothek_und_Konservatorium_Amsterdam.jpg)

Philip Vingboons designed splendid merchants' houses throughout the city. A famous building in [baroque style](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") in Amsterdam is the [Royal Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") on [Dam Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"). Throughout the 18th century, Amsterdam was heavily influenced by [French culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_France "Culture of France"). This is reflected in the architecture of that period. Around 1815, architects broke with the baroque style and started building in different neo-styles.<sup id="cite_ref-neostijl_173-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-neostijl-173">[173]</a></sup> Most Gothic style buildings date from that era and are therefore said to be built in a [neo-gothic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") style. At the end of the 19th century, the [Jugendstil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") or [Art Nouveau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") style became popular and many new buildings were constructed in this architectural style. Since Amsterdam expanded rapidly during this period, new buildings adjacent to the city centre were also built in this style. The houses in the vicinity of the [Museum Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") in Amsterdam Oud-Zuid are an example of Jugendstil. The last style that was popular in Amsterdam before the [modern era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_history "Modern history") was [Art Deco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco"). Amsterdam had its own version of the style, which was called the [Amsterdamse School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_School "Amsterdam School"). Whole districts were built this style, such as the _Rivierenbuurt_.<sup id="cite_ref-aschool_174-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-aschool-174">[174]</a></sup> A notable feature of the façades of buildings designed in Amsterdamse School is that they are highly decorated and ornate, with oddly shaped windows and doors.

The old city centre is the focal point of all the architectural styles before the end of the 19th century. Jugendstil and Georgian are mostly found outside the city's centre in the neighbourhoods built in the early 20th century, although there are also some striking examples of these styles in the city centre. Most historic buildings in the city centre and nearby are houses, such as the famous merchants' houses lining the canals.

### Parks and recreational areas\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Parks and recreational areas")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png/220px-Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_map_indicating_parks_-_01.png)

-   A: [Vondelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark")
-   B: [Beatrixpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beatrixpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Beatrixpark (page does not exist)")
-   C: [Sarphatipark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarphatipark "Sarphatipark")
-   D: [Oosterpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oosterpark_(Amsterdam) "Oosterpark (Amsterdam)")
-   E: [Park Frankendael](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Park_Frankendael&action=edit&redlink=1 "Park Frankendael (page does not exist)")
-   F: [Rembrandtpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandtpark "Rembrandtpark")
-   G: [Westerpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westerpark_(park) "Westerpark (park)")
-   H: [Flevopark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flevopark "Flevopark")
-   I: [Amsterdamse Bos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdamse_Bos "Amsterdamse Bos")
-   J: [Amstelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelpark "Amstelpark")
-   K: [Hortus Botanicus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortus_Botanicus_(Amsterdam) "Hortus Botanicus (Amsterdam)")
-   L: [Wertheimerpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wertheimerpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wertheimerpark (page does not exist)")
-   M: [Martin Luther Kingpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther_Kingpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Martin Luther Kingpark (page does not exist)")
-   N: [Sloterpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sloterpark&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sloterpark (page does not exist)")

Amsterdam has many parks, open spaces, and squares throughout the city. The [Vondelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"), the largest park in the city, is located in the [Oud-Zuid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Oud-Zuid "Amsterdam Oud-Zuid") neighbourhood and is named after the 17th-century Amsterdam author [Joost van den Vondel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joost_van_den_Vondel "Joost van den Vondel"). Yearly, the park has around 10 million visitors. In the park is an open-air theatre, a playground and several [horeca](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horeca "Horeca") facilities. In the [Zuid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") borough, is the Beatrixpark, named after [Queen Beatrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beatrix_of_the_Netherlands "Beatrix of the Netherlands"). Between Amsterdam and [Amstelveen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") is the [Amsterdamse Bos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdamse_Bos "Amsterdamse Bos") ("Amsterdam Forest"), the largest recreational area in Amsterdam. Annually, almost 4.5 million people visit the park, which has a size of 1.000 hectares and is approximately three times the size of [Central Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Park "Central Park").<sup id="cite_ref-175"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> The [Amstelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelpark "Amstelpark") in the [Zuid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") borough houses the Rieker windmill, which dates to 1636. Other parks include the [Sarphatipark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarphatipark "Sarphatipark") in the [De Pijp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Pijp "De Pijp") neighbourhood, the [Oosterpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oosterpark_(Amsterdam) "Oosterpark (Amsterdam)") in the [Oost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") borough and the [Westerpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westerpark_(park) "Westerpark (park)") in the [Westerpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westerpark_(neighbourhood) "Westerpark (neighbourhood)") neighbourhood. The city has three beaches: Nemo Beach, Citybeach "Het stenen hoofd" (Silodam) and Blijburg, all located in the Centrum borough.

The city has many open squares (_plein_ in Dutch). The namesake of the city as the site of the original dam, [Dam Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), is the main city square and has the [Royal Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam") and [National Monument](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Monument_(Amsterdam) "National Monument (Amsterdam)"). [Museumplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") hosts various museums, including the [Rijksmuseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum"), [Van Gogh Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum"), and [Stedelijk Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam"). Other squares include [Rembrandtplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandtplein "Rembrandtplein"), [Muntplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muntplein,_Amsterdam "Muntplein, Amsterdam"), [Nieuwmarkt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nieuwmarkt "Nieuwmarkt"), [Leidseplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein"), [Spui](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spui_(Amsterdam) "Spui (Amsterdam)") and [Waterlooplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterlooplein "Waterlooplein"). Also, near to Amsterdam is the [Nekkeveld estate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekkeveld_estate "Nekkeveld estate") conservation project.

## Economy\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Economy")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/20151120_BeursvanBerlage_002-6972.jpg/250px-20151120_BeursvanBerlage_002-6972.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:20151120_BeursvanBerlage_002-6972.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg/250px-ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ZuidasAmsterdamNederland2011.jpg)

The [Zuidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas"), the city's main business district

Amsterdam is the financial and business capital of the Netherlands.<sup id="cite_ref-ez_176-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-ez-176">[176]</a></sup> According to the 2007 [European Cities Monitor](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Cities_Monitor&action=edit&redlink=1 "European Cities Monitor (page does not exist)") (ECM) – an annual location survey of Europe's leading companies carried out by global real estate consultant [Cushman & Wakefield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cushman_%26_Wakefield "Cushman & Wakefield") – Amsterdam is one of the top European cities in which to locate an [international business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_business "International business"), ranking fifth in the survey.<sup id="cite_ref-eubusiness_177-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-eubusiness-177">[177]</a></sup> with the survey determining London, Paris, [Frankfurt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt") and [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") as the four European cities surpassing Amsterdam in this regard.

A substantial number of large corporations and banks' headquarters are located in the Amsterdam area, including: [AkzoNobel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AkzoNobel "AkzoNobel"), [Heineken International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heineken_International "Heineken International"), [ING Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group"), [ABN AMRO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABN_AMRO "ABN AMRO"), [TomTom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TomTom "TomTom"), [Delta Lloyd Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delta_Lloyd_Group "Delta Lloyd Group"), [Booking.com](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Booking.com "Booking.com") and [Philips](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philips "Philips"). Although many small offices remain along the [historic canals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), centrally based companies have increasingly relocated outside [Amsterdam's city centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Centrum "Amsterdam-Centrum"). Consequently, the [Zuidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas") (English: South Axis) has become the new financial and legal hub of Amsterdam,<sup id="cite_ref-zuidas_178-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-zuidas-178">[178]</a></sup> with the country's five largest law firms and several subsidiaries of large consulting firms, such as [Boston Consulting Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Consulting_Group "Boston Consulting Group") and [Accenture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), as well as the [World Trade Centre (Amsterdam)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(Amsterdam) "World Trade Center (Amsterdam)") located in the [Zuidas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zuidas "Zuidas") district. In addition to the Zuidas, there are three smaller [financial districts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_business_district "Central business district") in Amsterdam:

-   around [Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Sloterdijk_railway_station "Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station"). Where one can find the offices of several newspapers, such as _[De Telegraaf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Telegraaf "De Telegraaf")._ as well as those of [Deloitte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deloitte "Deloitte"), the [Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemeentelijk_Vervoerbedrijf "Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf") (municipal public transport company), and the [Dutch tax offices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_and_Customs_Administration "Tax and Customs Administration") (_Belastingdienst_);
-   around the [Johan Cruyff Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") in [Amsterdam Zuidoost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost"), with the headquarters of [ING Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group");
-   around the [Amstel railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station") in the [Amsterdam-Oost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") district to the east of the historical city. Amsterdam's [tallest building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures_in_the_world "List of tallest buildings and structures in the world"), the [Rembrandt Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandt_Tower "Rembrandt Tower"), is located here.<sup id="cite_ref-rembrandtoren_179-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-rembrandtoren-179">[179]</a></sup> As are the headquarters of [Philips](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philips "Philips"), the Dutch multinational conglomerate.<sup id="cite_ref-philips_180-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-philips-180">[180]</a></sup> Amsterdam has been a leading city to reduce the use of [raw materials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raw_material "Raw material") and has created a plan to become a [circular city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_economy "Circular economy") by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-181"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup>

The adjoining municipality of [Amstelveen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") is the location of [KPMG International's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPMG "KPMG") global headquarters. Other non-Dutch companies have chosen to settle in communities surrounding Amsterdam since they allow [freehold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freehold_(law) "Freehold (law)") property ownership, whereas Amsterdam retains [ground rent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_rent "Ground rent").

The [Amsterdam Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Stock_Exchange "Amsterdam Stock Exchange") (AEX), now part of [Euronext](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euronext "Euronext"), is the world's oldest stock exchange and, due to [Brexit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brexit "Brexit"), has overtaken [LSE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange") as the largest bourse in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-182"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> It is near [Dam Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square") in the city centre.

### Port of Amsterdam\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Port of Amsterdam")\]

The [Port of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam") is the fourth-largest port in Europe, the 38th largest port in the world and the second-largest port in the Netherlands by metric tons of cargo. In 2014, the Port of Amsterdam had a cargo throughput of 97,4 million tons of cargo, which was mostly [bulk cargo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulk_cargo "Bulk cargo"). Amsterdam has the biggest cruise port in the Netherlands with more than 150 cruise ships every year. In 2019, the new lock in IJmuiden opened; since then, the port has been able to grow to 125 million tonnes in capacity.

### Tourism\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Tourism")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat%2C_Rederij_Lovers%2C_Amsterdam-9218.jpg/220px-Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat%2C_Rederij_Lovers%2C_Amsterdam-9218.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wim_Sonneveld_tour_boat,_Rederij_Lovers,_Amsterdam-9218.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg/220px-Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Brug_97_in_de_Spiegelgracht_over_de_Lijnbaansgracht_foto_1.jpg)

Amsterdam is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe, receiving more than 5.34 million international visitors annually; this is excluding the 16 million day-trippers visiting the city every year.<sup id="cite_ref-ams2009_183-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-ams2009-183">[183]</a></sup> The number of visitors has been growing steadily over the past decade. This can be attributed to an increasing number of European visitors. Two-thirds of the hotels are located in the city's centre.<sup id="cite_ref-Maps_of_the_Netherlands_184-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Maps_of_the_Netherlands-184">[184]</a></sup> Hotels with 4 or 5 stars contribute 42% of the total beds available and 41% of the overnight stays in Amsterdam. The room occupation rate was 85% in 2017, up from 78% in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-Dutch_Hotel_City_Index_2019_185-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Dutch_Hotel_City_Index_2019-185">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TourismReport_186-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-TourismReport-186">[186]</a></sup> The majority of tourists (74%) originate from Europe. The largest group of non-European visitors come from the United States, accounting for 14% of the total.<sup id="cite_ref-TourismReport_186-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-TourismReport-186">[186]</a></sup> Certain years have a theme in Amsterdam to attract extra tourists. For example, the year 2006 was designated "Rembrandt 400", to celebrate the 400th birthday of [Rembrandt van Rijn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"). Some hotels offer special arrangements or activities during these years. The average number of guests per year staying at the four campsites around the city range from 12,000 to 65,000.<sup id="cite_ref-TourismReport_186-2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-TourismReport-186">[186]</a></sup>

#### De Wallen (red-light district)\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: De Wallen (red-light district)")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG/220px-Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Red-light_district_of_Amsterdam_by_day._2012.JPG)

De Wallen, also known as Walletjes or Rosse Buurt, is a designated area for [legalised prostitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prostitution_in_the_Netherlands "Prostitution in the Netherlands") and is Amsterdam's largest and best-known [red-light district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-light_district "Red-light district"). This neighbourhood has become a famous attraction for tourists. It consists of a network of canals, streets, and alleys containing several hundred small, one-room apartments rented by [sex workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sex_worker "Sex worker") who offer their services from behind a window or glass door, typically illuminated with red lights. In recent years, the city government has been closing and repurposing the famous red-light district windows in an effort to clean up the area and reduce the amount of party and sex tourism.

### Retail\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Retail")\]

Shops in Amsterdam range from large high-end department stores such as [De Bijenkorf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Bijenkorf "De Bijenkorf") founded in 1870 to small speciality shops. Amsterdam's high-end shops are found in the streets [P.C. Hooftstraat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P.C._Hooftstraat "P.C. Hooftstraat")<sup id="cite_ref-hoof_cite_188-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-hoof_cite-188">[188]</a></sup> and _Cornelis Schuytstraat_, which are located in the vicinity of the [Vondelpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vondelpark "Vondelpark"). One of Amsterdam's busiest high streets is the narrow, medieval [Kalverstraat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalverstraat "Kalverstraat") in the heart of the city. Other shopping areas include the _Negen Straatjes_ and Haarlemmerdijk and Haarlemmerstraat. _Negen Straatjes_ are nine narrow streets within the _Grachtengordel_, the concentric canal system of Amsterdam. The Negen Straatjes differ from other shopping districts with the presence of a large diversity of privately owned shops. The Haarlemmerstraat and Haarlemmerdijk were voted best shopping street in the Netherlands in 2011. These streets have as the _Negen Straatjes_ a large diversity of privately owned shops. However, as the _Negen Straatjes_ are dominated by fashion stores, the Haarlemmerstraat and Haarlemmerdijk offer a wide variety of stores, just to name some specialities: candy and other food-related stores, lingerie, sneakers, wedding clothing, interior shops, books, Italian deli's, racing and mountain bikes, skatewear, etc.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (March 2023)">original research?</span></a></i>]</sup>

The city also features a large number of open-air markets such as the [Albert Cuyp Market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Cuyp_Market "Albert Cuyp Market"), Westerstraat-markt, Ten Katemarkt, and [Dappermarkt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dappermarkt "Dappermarkt"). Some of these markets are held daily, like the Albert Cuypmarkt and the Dappermarkt. Others, like the Westerstraatmarkt, are held every week.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (March 2023)">original research?</span></a></i>]</sup>

### Fashion\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Fashion")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/AmsterdamBikeGirl.png/220px-AmsterdamBikeGirl.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AmsterdamBikeGirl.png)

An Amsterdammer waits for a traffic light to change at the Muntplein in the heart of Amsterdam.

Several fashion brands and designers are based in Amsterdam. Fashion designers include [Iris van Herpen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iris_van_Herpen "Iris van Herpen"),<sup id="cite_ref-189"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> [Mart Visser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mart_Visser "Mart Visser"), [Viktor & Rolf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viktor_%26_Rolf "Viktor & Rolf"), [Marlies Dekkers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marlies_Dekkers "Marlies Dekkers") and [Frans Molenaar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frans_Molenaar "Frans Molenaar"). Fashion models like [Yfke Sturm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yfke_Sturm "Yfke Sturm"), [Doutzen Kroes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doutzen_Kroes "Doutzen Kroes") and Kim Noorda started their careers in Amsterdam. Amsterdam has its garment centre in the World Fashion Center. Fashion photographers [Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inez_and_Vinoodh "Inez and Vinoodh") were born in Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-190"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup>

## Culture\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Culture")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Amsterdam_rijkmuseum.JPG/220px-Amsterdam_rijkmuseum.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_rijkmuseum.JPG)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Van_Gogh_Museum_by_night_Amsterdam_2017.jpg/220px-Van_Gogh_Museum_by_night_Amsterdam_2017.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Van_Gogh_Museum_by_night_Amsterdam_2017.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:De_nieuwe_vleugel_van_het_Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam.jpg)

During the later part of the 16th century, Amsterdam's Rederijkerskamer ([Chamber of rhetoric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_of_rhetoric "Chamber of rhetoric")) organised contests between different Chambers in the reading of poetry and drama.<sup id="cite_ref-191"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> In 1637, [Schouwburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schouwburg "Schouwburg"), the first theatre in Amsterdam was built, opening on 3 January 1638.<sup id="cite_ref-193"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> The first ballet performances in the Netherlands were given in Schouwburg in 1642 with the _Ballet of the Five Senses_.<sup id="cite_ref-194"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> In the 18th century, French theatre became popular. While Amsterdam was under the influence of German music in the 19th century there were few national opera productions; the Hollandse Opera of Amsterdam was built in 1888 for the specific purpose of promoting Dutch opera.<sup id="cite_ref-196"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> In the 19th century, popular culture was centred on the Nes area in Amsterdam (mainly [vaudeville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaudeville "Vaudeville") and [music-hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_hall "Music hall")).<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2008)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> An improved [metronome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metronome "Metronome") was invented in 1812 by [Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_Nikolaus_Winkel "Dietrich Nikolaus Winkel").<sup id="cite_ref-197"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> The [Rijksmuseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum") (1885) and [Stedelijk Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam") (1895) were built and opened.<sup id="cite_ref-198"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> In 1888, the [Concertgebouworkest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Concertgebouw_Orchestra "Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra") orchestra was established.<sup id="cite_ref-200"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> With the 20th century came cinema, radio and television.<sup>[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2008)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Though most studios are located in [Hilversum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilversum "Hilversum") and [Aalsmeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aalsmeer "Aalsmeer"), Amsterdam's influence on programming is very strong. Many people who work in the television industry live in Amsterdam. Also, the headquarters of the Dutch [SBS Broadcasting Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SBS_6 "SBS 6") is located in Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-sbs6_201-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-sbs6-201">[201]</a></sup>

### Museums\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Museums")\]

The most important museums of Amsterdam are located on the [Museumplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museumplein "Museumplein") (Museum Square), located at the southwestern side of the Rijksmuseum. It was created in the last quarter of the 19th century on the grounds of the former [World's fair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internationale_Koloniale_en_Uitvoerhandel_Tentoonstelling "Internationale Koloniale en Uitvoerhandel Tentoonstelling"). The northeastern part of the square is bordered by the large Rijksmuseum. In front of the Rijksmuseum on the square itself is a long, rectangular pond. This is transformed into an ice rink in winter.<sup id="cite_ref-ijsbaan_202-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-ijsbaan-202">[202]</a></sup> The northwestern part of the square is bordered by the Van Gogh Museum, House of Bols Cocktail & Genever Experience and Coster Diamonds. The southwestern border of the Museum Square is the Van Baerlestraat, which is a major thoroughfare in this part of Amsterdam. The Concertgebouw is located across this street from the square. To the southeast of the square are several large houses, one of which contains the American consulate. A [parking garage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-storey_car_park "Multi-storey car park") can be found underneath the square, as well as a supermarket. The Museumplein is covered almost entirely with a lawn, except for the northeastern part of the square which is covered with gravel. The current appearance of the square was realised in 1999, when the square was remodelled. The square itself is the most prominent site in Amsterdam for festivals and outdoor concerts, especially in the summer. Plans were made in 2008 to remodel the square again because many inhabitants of Amsterdam are not happy with its current appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-museumpleinfacelift_203-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-museumpleinfacelift-203">[203]</a></sup>

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Rembrandt.JPG/180px-Rembrandt.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rembrandt.JPG)

The [Rijksmuseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rijksmuseum "Rijksmuseum") possesses the largest and most important collection of classical [Dutch art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_art "Dutch art").<sup id="cite_ref-204"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> It opened in 1885. Its collection consists of nearly one million objects.<sup id="cite_ref-205"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> The artist most associated with Amsterdam is [Rembrandt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"), whose work, and the work of his pupils, is displayed in the Rijksmuseum. Rembrandt's masterpiece _[The Night Watch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Night_Watch "The Night Watch")_ is one of the top pieces of art of the museum. It also houses paintings from artists like [Bartholomeus van der Helst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bartholomeus_van_der_Helst "Bartholomeus van der Helst"), [Johannes Vermeer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Vermeer "Johannes Vermeer"), [Frans Hals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frans_Hals "Frans Hals"), [Ferdinand Bol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Bol "Ferdinand Bol"), [Albert Cuyp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aelbert_Cuyp "Aelbert Cuyp"), [Jacob van Ruisdael](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacob_van_Ruisdael "Jacob van Ruisdael") and [Paulus Potter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paulus_Potter "Paulus Potter"). Aside from paintings, the collection consists of a large variety of [decorative art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decorative_arts "Decorative arts"). This ranges from [Delftware](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delftware "Delftware") to giant doll-houses from the 17th century. The architect of the [gothic revival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival architecture") building was P.J.H. Cuypers. The museum underwent a 10-year, 375 million euro renovation starting in 2003. The full collection was reopened to the public on 13 April 2013 and the Rijksmuseum has remained the most visited museum in Amsterdam with 2.2 million visitors in 2016 and 2.16 million in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-206"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>

Van Gogh lived in Amsterdam for a short while and there is a [museum dedicated to his work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Van_Gogh_Museum "Van Gogh Museum"). The museum is housed in one of the few modern buildings in this area of Amsterdam. The building was designed by [Gerrit Rietveld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrit_Rietveld "Gerrit Rietveld"). This building is where the permanent collection is displayed. A new building was added to the museum in 1999. This building, known as the performance wing, was designed by Japanese architect [Kisho Kurokawa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kisho_Kurokawa "Kisho Kurokawa"). Its purpose is to house temporary exhibitions of the museum.<sup id="cite_ref-vangogh3_207-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-vangogh3-207">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> Some of Van Gogh's most famous paintings, like _[The Potato Eaters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Potato_Eaters "The Potato Eaters")_ and _[Sunflowers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunflowers_(series_of_paintings) "Sunflowers (series of paintings)")_, are in the collection.<sup id="cite_ref-209"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> The Van Gogh museum is the second most visited museum in Amsterdam, not far behind the Rijksmuseum in terms of the number of visits, being approximately 2.1 million in 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-210"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> for example.

Next to the Van Gogh museum stands the [Stedelijk Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stedelijk_Museum_Amsterdam "Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam"). This is Amsterdam's most important museum of modern art. The museum is as old as the square it borders and was opened in 1895. The permanent collection consists of works of art from artists like [Piet Mondrian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piet_Mondrian "Piet Mondrian"), [Karel Appel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karel_Appel "Karel Appel"), and [Kazimir Malevich](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich "Kazimir Malevich"). After renovations lasting several years, the museum opened in September 2012 with a new composite extension that has been called 'The Bathtub' due to its resemblance to one.

Amsterdam contains many other museums throughout the city. They range from small museums such as the [Verzetsmuseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verzetsmuseum "Verzetsmuseum") (Resistance Museum), the [Anne Frank House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anne_Frank_House "Anne Frank House"), and the [Rembrandt House Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandt_House_Museum "Rembrandt House Museum"), to the very large, like the [Tropenmuseum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropenmuseum "Tropenmuseum") (Museum of the Tropics), [Amsterdam Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Museum "Amsterdam Museum") (formerly known as Amsterdam Historical Museum), [Hermitage Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermitage_Amsterdam "Hermitage Amsterdam") (a dependency of the [Hermitage Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermitage_Museum "Hermitage Museum") in Saint Petersburg) and the [Joods Historisch Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joods_Historisch_Museum "Joods Historisch Museum") (Jewish Historical Museum). The modern-styled [Nemo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NEMO_(museum) "NEMO (museum)") is dedicated to child-friendly science exhibitions.

### Music\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Music")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22%2C_Amsterdam_Arena%2C_June_2016_%285%29.jpg/220px-Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22%2C_Amsterdam_Arena%2C_June_2016_%285%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Coldplay_perform_%22Adventure_of_a_Lifetime%22,_Amsterdam_Arena,_June_2016_(5).jpg)

Amsterdam's musical culture includes a large collection of songs that treat the city nostalgically and lovingly. The 1949 song "Aan de Amsterdamse grachten" ("On the canals of Amsterdam") was performed and recorded by many artists, including [John Kraaijkamp Sr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Kraaijkamp_Sr. "John Kraaijkamp Sr."); the best-known version is probably that by [Wim Sonneveld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wim_Sonneveld "Wim Sonneveld") (1962). In the 1950s [Johnny Jordaan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Jordaan "Johnny Jordaan") rose to fame with "[Geef mij maar Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geef_mij_maar_Amsterdam "Geef mij maar Amsterdam")" ("I prefer Amsterdam"), which praises the city above all others (explicitly Paris); Jordaan sang especially about his own neighbourhood, the [Jordaan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordaan "Jordaan") ("Bij ons in de Jordaan"). Colleagues and contemporaries of Johnny include [Tante Leen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tante_Leen "Tante Leen") and [Manke Nelis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manke_Nelis "Manke Nelis"). Another notable Amsterdam song is "[Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_(Jacques_Brel_song) "Amsterdam (Jacques Brel song)")" by [Jacques Brel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Brel "Jacques Brel") (1964).<sup id="cite_ref-lijflied_finale_211-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-lijflied_finale-211">[211]</a></sup> A 2011 poll by Amsterdam newspaper _[Het Parool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Het_Parool "Het Parool")_ that Trio Bier's "Oude Wolf" was voted "Amsterdams lijflied".<sup id="cite_ref-212"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> Notable Amsterdam bands from the modern era include the [Osdorp Posse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osdorp_Posse "Osdorp Posse") and [The Ex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ex_(band) "The Ex (band)").

[AFAS Live](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFAS_Live "AFAS Live") (formerly known as the Heineken Music Hall) is a concert hall located near the [Johan Cruyff Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") (known as the Amsterdam Arena until 2018). Its main purpose is to serve as a podium for pop concerts for big audiences. Many famous international artists have performed there. Two other notable venues, [Paradiso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and the [Melkweg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg") are located near the [Leidseplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein"). Both focus on broad programming, ranging from [indie rock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indie_rock "Indie rock") to [hip hop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music"), [R&B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues "Rhythm and blues"), and other popular genres. Other more subcultural music venues are [OCCII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OCCII "OCCII"), [OT301](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OT301 "OT301"), De Nieuwe Anita, Winston Kingdom, and Zaal 100. [Jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") has a strong following in Amsterdam, with the [Bimhuis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bimhuis "Bimhuis") being the premier venue. In 2012, [Ziggo Dome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ziggo_Dome "Ziggo Dome") was opened, also near Amsterdam Arena, a state-of-the-art indoor music arena.

[AFAS Live](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFAS_Live "AFAS Live") is also host to many [electronic dance music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_dance_music "Electronic dance music") festivals, alongside many other venues. [Armin van Buuren](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armin_van_Buuren "Armin van Buuren") and [Tiesto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiesto "Tiesto"), some of the worlds leading [Trance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trance_music "Trance music") DJ's hail from the Netherlands and frequently perform in Amsterdam. Each year in October, the city hosts the Amsterdam Dance Event (ADE) which is one of the leading electronic music conferences and one of the biggest club festivals for electronic music in the world, attracting over 350,000 visitors each year.<sup id="cite_ref-213"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> Another popular dance festival is 5daysoff, which takes place in the venues [Paradiso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and [Melkweg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg"). In the summertime, there are several big outdoor dance parties in or nearby Amsterdam, such as Awakenings, [Dance Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance_Valley "Dance Valley"), [Mystery Land](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysteryland "Mysteryland"), Loveland, A Day at the Park, Welcome to the Future, and Valtifest.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Concertgebouw%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg/220px-Concertgebouw%2C_%C3%81msterdam%2C_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos%2C_2016-05-30%2C_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Concertgebouw,_%C3%81msterdam,_Pa%C3%ADses_Bajos,_2016-05-30,_DD_22-24_HDR.jpg)

Amsterdam has a world-class symphony orchestra, the [Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Concertgebouw_Orchestra "Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra"). Their home is the [Concertgebouw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concertgebouw,_Amsterdam "Concertgebouw, Amsterdam"), which is across the Van Baerlestraat from the Museum Square. It is considered by critics to be a [concert hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_concert_halls "List of concert halls") with some of the best [acoustics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acoustics "Acoustics") in the world. The building contains three halls, Grote Zaal, Kleine Zaal, and Spiegelzaal. Some nine hundred concerts and other events per year take place in the Concertgebouw, for a public of over 700,000, making it one of the most-visited concert halls in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-214"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> The opera house of Amsterdam is located adjacent to the city hall. Therefore, the two buildings combined are often called the [Stopera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stopera "Stopera"), (a word originally coined by protesters against it very construction: _Stop the Opera\[-house\]_). This huge modern complex, opened in 1986, lies in the former Jewish neighbourhood at _Waterlooplein_ next to the river [Amstel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstel "Amstel"). The _Stopera_ is the home base of [Dutch National Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_National_Opera "Dutch National Opera"), [Dutch National Ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_National_Ballet "Dutch National Ballet") and the [Holland Symfonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holland_Symfonia "Holland Symfonia"). [Muziekgebouw aan 't IJ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muziekgebouw_aan_%27t_IJ "Muziekgebouw aan 't IJ") is a concert hall, which is located in the [IJ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") near the central station. Its concerts perform mostly [modern classical music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/20th-century_classical_music "20th-century classical music"). Located adjacent to it, is the _[Bimhuis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bimhuis "Bimhuis")_, a concert hall for improvised and [Jazz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") music.

### Performing arts\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]

Amsterdam has three main theatre buildings.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg/220px-Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Stadsschouwburg_amsterdam.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Theater_carre.jpg/220px-Theater_carre.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Theater_carre.jpg)

The [Stadsschouwburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stadsschouwburg "Stadsschouwburg") at the [Leidseplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein") is the home base of [Toneelgroep Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toneelgroep_Amsterdam "Toneelgroep Amsterdam"). The current building dates from 1894. Most plays are performed in the Grote Zaal (Great Hall). The normal program of events encompasses all sorts of theatrical forms. In 2009, the new hall of the Stadsschouwburg Amsterdam, Toneelgroep Amsterdam and Melkweg opened, and the renovation of the front end of the theatre was ready.

The [Dutch National Opera and Ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stopera "Stopera") (formerly known as _Het Muziektheater_), dating from 1986, is the principal opera house and home to [Dutch National Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_National_Opera "Dutch National Opera") and [Dutch National Ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_National_Ballet "Dutch National Ballet"). [Royal Theatre Carré](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carr%C3%A9_Theatre "Carré Theatre") was built as a permanent circus theatre in 1887 and is currently mainly used for musicals, [cabaret](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabaret "Cabaret") performances, and pop concerts.

The recently re-opened DeLaMar Theater houses more commercial plays and musicals. A new theatre has also moved into the Amsterdam scene in 2014, joining other established venues: Theater Amsterdam is located in the west part of Amsterdam, on the Danzigerkade. It is housed in a modern building with a panoramic view over the harbour. The theatre is the first-ever purpose-built venue to showcase a single play entitled ANNE, the play based on Anne Frank's life.

On the east side of town, there is a small theatre in a converted bathhouse, the [Badhuistheater](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Badhuistheater "Badhuistheater"). The theatre often has English programming.

The Netherlands has a tradition of cabaret or _kleinkunst_, which combines music, storytelling, commentary, theatre and comedy. Cabaret dates back to the 1930s and artists like [Wim Kan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wim_Kan "Wim Kan"), [Wim Sonneveld](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wim_Sonneveld "Wim Sonneveld") and [Toon Hermans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toon_Hermans "Toon Hermans") were pioneers of this form of art in the Netherlands. In Amsterdam is the Kleinkunstacademie (English: Cabaret Academy) and [Nederlied](https://nederlied.nl/) Kleinkunstkoor (English: Cabaret Choir). Contemporary popular artists are [Youp van 't Hek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youp_van_%27t_Hek "Youp van 't Hek"), [Freek de Jonge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freek_de_Jonge "Freek de Jonge"), [Herman Finkers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Finkers "Herman Finkers"), [Hans Teeuwen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Teeuwen "Hans Teeuwen"), [Theo Maassen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theo_Maassen "Theo Maassen"), [Herman van Veen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_van_Veen "Herman van Veen"), [Najib Amhali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Najib_Amhali "Najib Amhali"), [Raoul Heertje](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raoul_Heertje "Raoul Heertje"), [Jörgen Raymann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%B6rgen_Raymann "Jörgen Raymann"), [Brigitte Kaandorp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brigitte_Kaandorp "Brigitte Kaandorp") and [Comedytrain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comedytrain "Comedytrain"). The English spoken comedy scene was established with the founding of [Boom Chicago](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boom_Chicago "Boom Chicago") in 1993. They have their own theatre at Leidseplein.

### Nightlife\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg/200px-DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DeWolff_Paradiso.jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg/200px-Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Magere_Brug.jpg)

Amsterdam is famous for its vibrant and diverse nightlife. Amsterdam has many _[cafés](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_(establishment) "Bar (establishment)")_ (bars). They range from large and modern to small and cosy. The typical _Bruine Kroeg_ (brown _café_) breathe a more old fashioned atmosphere with dimmed lights, candles, and somewhat older clientele. These brown cafés mostly offer a wide range of local and international artisanal beers. Most _cafés_ have terraces in summertime. A common sight on the Leidseplein during summer is a square full of terraces packed with people drinking beer or wine. Many restaurants can be found in Amsterdam as well. Since Amsterdam is a multicultural city, a lot of different ethnic restaurants can be found. Restaurants range from being rather luxurious and expensive to being ordinary and affordable. Amsterdam also possesses many [discothèques](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discoth%C3%A8que "Discothèque"). The two main nightlife areas for tourists are the [Leidseplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leidseplein "Leidseplein") and the [Rembrandtplein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rembrandtplein "Rembrandtplein"). The [Paradiso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)"), [Melkweg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melkweg "Melkweg") and Sugar Factory are cultural centres, which turn into discothèques on some nights. Examples of discothèques near the Rembrandtplein are the Escape, Air, John Doe and Club Abe. Also noteworthy are Panama, Hotel Arena (East), TrouwAmsterdam and Studio 80. In recent years '24-hour' clubs opened their doors, most notably Radion De School, Shelter and Marktkantine. [Bimhuis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bimhuis "Bimhuis") located near the Central Station, with its rich programming hosting the best in the field is considered one of the best jazz clubs in the world. The Reguliersdwarsstraat is the main street for the [LGBT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT "LGBT") community and nightlife.

### Festivals\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Festivals")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_%288697415382%29.jpg/200px-Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_%288697415382%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Queen%27s_Day_in_Amsterdam_2013_(8697415382).jpg)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg/200px-Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam%27s_Canals.jpg)

In 2008, there were 140 festivals and events in Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-festivals_215-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-festivals-215">[215]</a></sup> During the same year, Amsterdam was designated as the [World Book Capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") for one year by [UNESCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").<sup id="cite_ref-216"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup>

Famous festivals and events in Amsterdam include: _[Koningsdag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koningsdag "Koningsdag")_ (which was named _Koninginnedag_ until the crowning of King Willem-Alexander in 2013) (King's Day – Queen's Day); the [Holland Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holland_Festival "Holland Festival") for the performing arts; the yearly [Prinsengrachtconcert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prinsengrachtconcert "Prinsengrachtconcert") (classical concerto on the Prinsen canal) in August; the '[Stille Omgang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stille_Omgang "Stille Omgang")' (a silent Roman Catholic evening procession held every March); [Amsterdam Gay Pride](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride "Amsterdam Gay Pride"); The [Cannabis Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_Cup "Cannabis Cup"); and the [Uitmarkt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uitmarkt "Uitmarkt"). On Koningsdag—that is held each year on 27 April—hundreds of thousands of people travel to Amsterdam to celebrate with the city's residents. The entire city becomes overcrowded with people buying products from the _freemarket_, or visiting one of the many music concerts.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG/220px-Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Gay_Pride_2013_boat_no37_Hot_Spot_Cafe_pic7.JPG)

The yearly Holland Festival attracts international artists and visitors from all over Europe. [Amsterdam Gay Pride](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Gay_Pride "Amsterdam Gay Pride") is a yearly local LGBT parade of boats in Amsterdam's canals, held on the first Saturday in August.<sup id="cite_ref-gaypride_217-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-gaypride-217">[217]</a></sup> The annual Uitmarkt is a three-day cultural event at the start of the cultural season in late August. It offers previews of many different artists, such as musicians and poets, who perform on [podia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podium "Podium").<sup id="cite_ref-uitmarkt_218-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-uitmarkt-218">[218]</a></sup>

## Sports\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Sports")\]

Amsterdam is home of the _[Eredivisie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eredivisie "Eredivisie")_ football club [AFC Ajax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax"). The stadium [Johan Cruyff Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_Cruyff_Arena "Johan Cruyff Arena") is the home of Ajax. It is located in the [south-east](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost") of the city next to the new [Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Bijlmer_ArenA_railway_station "Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station"). Before moving to their current location in 1996, Ajax played their regular matches in the now demolished [De Meer Stadion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Meer_Stadion "De Meer Stadion") in the eastern part of the city<sup id="cite_ref-219"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> or in the [Olympic Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Amsterdam) "Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)"). In 1928, Amsterdam hosted the [Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1928_Summer_Olympics "1928 Summer Olympics"). The [Olympic Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Stadium_(Amsterdam) "Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)") built for the occasion has been completely restored and is now used for cultural and sporting events, such as the [Amsterdam Marathon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Marathon "Amsterdam Marathon").<sup id="cite_ref-220"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> In 1920, Amsterdam assisted in hosting some of the [sailing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sailing_at_the_1920_Summer_Olympics "Sailing at the 1920 Summer Olympics") events for the [Summer Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics "1920 Summer Olympics") held in neighbouring [Antwerp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp"), Belgium by hosting events at [Buiten IJ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)").

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg/220px-Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Feyenoord_tegen_Ajax_1-0._Nummer_26_Israel_in_duel_met_Cruyff.jpg)

The city holds the [Dam to Dam Run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_tot_Damloop "Dam tot Damloop"), a 16 km (10 mi) race from Amsterdam to [Zaandam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaandam "Zaandam"), as well as the [Amsterdam Marathon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Marathon "Amsterdam Marathon"). The ice hockey team [Amstel Tijgers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstel_Tijgers "Amstel Tijgers") play in the [Jaap Eden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaap_Eden "Jaap Eden") ice rink. The team competes in the Dutch ice hockey premier league. [Speed skating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_track_speed_skating "Long track speed skating") championships have been held on the 400-meter lane of this ice rink.

Amsterdam holds two [American football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football "American football") franchises: the [Amsterdam Crusaders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Crusaders "Amsterdam Crusaders") and the Amsterdam Panthers. The [Amsterdam Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Pirates "Amsterdam Pirates") baseball team competes in the [Dutch Major League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honkbal_Hoofdklasse "Honkbal Hoofdklasse"). There are three [field hockey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey") teams: Amsterdam, Pinoké and Hurley, who play their matches around the [Wagener Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wagener_Stadium "Wagener Stadium") in the nearby city of [Amstelveen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen"). The basketball team [MyGuide Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MyGuide_Amsterdam "MyGuide Amsterdam") competes in the Dutch premier division and play their games in the Sporthallen Zuid.<sup id="cite_ref-221"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup>

There is one rugby club in Amsterdam, which also hosts sports training classes such as RTC (Rugby Talenten Centrum or Rugby Talent Centre) and the National Rugby stadium.

Since 1999, the city of Amsterdam honours the best sportsmen and women at the [Amsterdam Sports Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Sportsman_of_the_year "Amsterdam Sportsman of the year"). Boxer [Raymond Joval](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raymond_Joval "Raymond Joval") and field hockey midfielder [Carole Thate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carole_Thate "Carole Thate") were the first to receive the awards, in 1999.

Amsterdam hosted the [World Gymnaestrada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Gymnaestrada "World Gymnaestrada") in 1991 and will do so again in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-222"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>

## Politics\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Politics")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Femke_Halsema_2.jpg/200px-Femke_Halsema_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Femke_Halsema_2.jpg)

The city of Amsterdam is a [municipality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") under the Dutch Municipalities Act. It is governed by a directly elected [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"), a [municipal executive board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_van_burgemeester_en_wethouders "College van burgemeester en wethouders") and a [mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester"). Since 1981, the [municipality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam has gradually been divided into semi-autonomous [boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam"), called _stadsdelen_ or 'districts'. Over time, a total of 15 boroughs were created. In May 2010, under a major reform, the number of [Amsterdam boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") was reduced to eight: [Amsterdam-Centrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Centrum "Amsterdam-Centrum") covering the city centre including the [canal belt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canals_of_Amsterdam "Canals of Amsterdam"), [Amsterdam-Noord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord") consisting of the neighbourhoods north of the [IJ lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)"), [Amsterdam-Oost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Oost "Amsterdam-Oost") in the east, [Amsterdam-Zuid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Zuid "Amsterdam-Zuid") in the south, [Amsterdam-West](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-West "Amsterdam-West") in the west, [Amsterdam Nieuw-West](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Nieuw-West "Amsterdam Nieuw-West") in the far west, [Amsterdam Zuidoost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuidoost "Amsterdam Zuidoost") in the southeast, and [Westpoort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westpoort_(Amsterdam) "Westpoort (Amsterdam)") covering the [Port of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Amsterdam "Port of Amsterdam") area.<sup id="cite_ref-223"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup>

### City government\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: City government")\]

As with all Dutch municipalities, Amsterdam is governed by a directly elected [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"), a [municipal executive board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_van_burgemeester_en_wethouders "College van burgemeester en wethouders") and a government appointed<sup id="cite_ref-224"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> [mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester") (_burgemeester_). The mayor is a member of the municipal executive board, but also has individual responsibilities in maintaining public order. On 27 June 2018, [Femke Halsema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Femke_Halsema "Femke Halsema") (former member of [House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Netherlands) "House of Representatives (Netherlands)") for [GroenLinks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GroenLinks "GroenLinks") from 1998 to 2011) was appointed as the first woman to be [Mayor of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Amsterdam "List of mayors of Amsterdam") by the [King's Commissioner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King%27s_Commissioner "King's Commissioner") of [North Holland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Holland "North Holland") for a six-year term after being nominated by the Amsterdam [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)") and began serving a six-year term on 12 July 2018. She replaces [Eberhard van der Laan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eberhard_van_der_Laan "Eberhard van der Laan") ([Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(Netherlands) "Labour Party (Netherlands)")) who was the Mayor of Amsterdam from 2010 until his death in October 2017.
