After the [2014 municipal council elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_municipal_elections,_2014 "Dutch municipal elections, 2014"), a governing majority of [D66](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democrats_66 "Democrats 66"), [VVD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Party_for_Freedom_and_Democracy "People's Party for Freedom and Democracy") and [SP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Netherlands) "Socialist Party (Netherlands)") was formed – the first coalition without the [Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(Netherlands) "Labour Party (Netherlands)") since [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").<sup id="cite_ref-225"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> Next to the [Mayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burgemeester "Burgemeester"), the [municipal executive board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_van_burgemeester_en_wethouders "College van burgemeester en wethouders") consists of eight _wethouders_ ('alderpersons') appointed by the [municipal council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipal_council_(Netherlands) "Municipal council (Netherlands)"): four [D66](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democrats_66 "Democrats 66") alderpersons, two [VVD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Party_for_Freedom_and_Democracy "People's Party for Freedom and Democracy") alderpersons and two [SP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Party_(Netherlands) "Socialist Party (Netherlands)") alderpersons.<sup id="cite_ref-226"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup>

On 18 September 2017, it was announced by [Eberhard van der Laan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eberhard_van_der_Laan "Eberhard van der Laan") in an open letter to Amsterdam citizens that [Kajsa Ollongren](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kajsa_Ollongren "Kajsa Ollongren") would take up his office as acting Mayor of Amsterdam with immediate effect due to ill health.<sup id="cite_ref-227"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> Ollongren was succeeded as acting Mayor by Eric van der Burg on 26 October 2017 and by [Jozias van Aartsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jozias_van_Aartsen "Jozias van Aartsen") on 4 December 2017.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png/250px-Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdamse_stadsdelen_2010.png)

Unlike most other Dutch municipalities, Amsterdam is subdivided into eight [boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam"), called _stadsdelen_ or 'districts', and the urban area of [Weesp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weesp "Weesp"), a system that was implemented gradually in the 1980s to improve local governance. The [boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") are responsible for many activities that had previously been run by the central city. In 2010, the number of [Amsterdam boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") reached fifteen. Fourteen of those had their own district council (_deelraad_), elected by a popular vote. The fifteenth, [Westpoort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westpoort "Westpoort"), covers the harbour of Amsterdam and had very few residents. Therefore, it was governed by the central municipal council.

Under the borough system, municipal decisions are made at borough level, except for those affairs pertaining to the whole city such as major infrastructure projects, which are the jurisdiction of the central municipal authorities. In 2010, the [borough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") system was restructured, in which many smaller boroughs merged into larger boroughs. In 2014, under a reform of the Dutch Municipalities Act, the [Amsterdam boroughs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") lost much of their autonomous status, as their district councils were abolished.

The municipal council of Amsterdam voted to maintain the borough system by replacing the district councils with smaller, but still directly elected district committees (_bestuurscommissies_). Under a municipal ordinance, the new district committees were granted responsibilities through delegation of regulatory and executive powers by the central municipal council.

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg/800px-Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Amstel.jpg)

### Metropolitan area\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Metropolitan area")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Police_Headquarters%2C_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Police_Headquarters%2C_Amsterdam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Police_Headquarters,_Amsterdam.jpg)

Police headquarters of Amsterdam

"Amsterdam" is usually understood to refer to the [municipality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam. Colloquially, some areas within the municipality, such as the town of [Durgerdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Durgerdam "Durgerdam"), may not be considered part of Amsterdam.

[Statistics Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics_Netherlands "Statistics Netherlands") uses three other definitions of Amsterdam: metropolitan agglomeration Amsterdam (_Grootstedelijke Agglomeratie Amsterdam_, not to be confused with _Grootstedelijk Gebied Amsterdam_, a synonym of _Groot Amsterdam_), Greater Amsterdam (_Groot Amsterdam_, a [COROP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COROP "COROP") region) and the urban region Amsterdam (_Stadsgewest Amsterdam_).<sup id="cite_ref-auto_114-2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-auto-114">[114]</a></sup> The Amsterdam Department for Research and Statistics uses a fourth conurbation, namely the _Stadsregio Amsterdam_ ('City Region of Amsterdam'). The city region is similar to Greater Amsterdam but includes the municipalities of [Zaanstad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaanstad "Zaanstad") and [Wormerland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wormerland "Wormerland"). It excludes [Graft-De Rijp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graft-De_Rijp "Graft-De Rijp").

The smallest of these areas is the [municipality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Municipalities_of_the_Netherlands "Municipalities of the Netherlands") of Amsterdam with a population of 802,938 in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs2013_228-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cbs2013-228">[228]</a></sup> The conurbation had a population of 1,096,042 in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs2013_228-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cbs2013-228">[228]</a></sup> It includes the municipalities of Zaanstad, Wormerland, Oostzaan, Diemen and Amstelveen only, as well as the municipality of Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs2013_228-2"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cbs2013-228">[228]</a></sup> Greater Amsterdam includes 15 municipalities,<sup id="cite_ref-cbs2013_228-3"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cbs2013-228">[228]</a></sup> and had a population of 1,293,208 in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs2013_228-4"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cbs2013-228">[228]</a></sup> Though much larger in area, the population of this area is only slightly larger, because the definition excludes the relatively populous municipality of [Zaanstad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaanstad "Zaanstad"). The largest area by population, the [Amsterdam Metropolitan Area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Metropolitan_Area "Amsterdam Metropolitan Area") (Dutch: Metropoolregio Amsterdam), has a population of 2,33 million.<sup id="cite_ref-dosamsterdam_229-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-dosamsterdam-229">[229]</a></sup> It includes for instance Zaanstad, Wormerland, Muiden, Abcoude, Haarlem, Almere and Lelystad but excludes Graft-De Rijp. Amsterdam is part of the conglomerate metropolitan area [Randstad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randstad "Randstad"), with a total population of 6,659,300 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-randstad_230-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-randstad-230">[230]</a></sup>

Of these various metropolitan area configurations, only the _Stadsregio Amsterdam_ (City Region of Amsterdam) has a formal governmental status. Its responsibilities include regional spatial planning and the metropolitan public transport concessions.<sup id="cite_ref-231"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup>

### National capital\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: National capital")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/King_Willem-Alexander%2C_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg/220px-King_Willem-Alexander%2C_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:King_Willem-Alexander,_Princess_Beatrix_en_Queen_Maxima.jpg)

Under the [Dutch Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Netherlands "Constitution of the Netherlands"), Amsterdam is the [capital of the Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_of_the_Netherlands "Capital of the Netherlands"). Since the 1983 constitutional revision, the constitution mentions "Amsterdam" and "capital" in chapter 2, article 32: The king's confirmation by oath and his coronation take place in "the capital Amsterdam" ("_de hoofdstad Amsterdam_").<sup id="cite_ref-capital-constitution_232-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-capital-constitution-232">[232]</a></sup> Previous versions of the constitution only mentioned "the city of Amsterdam" ("_de stad Amsterdam_").<sup id="cite_ref-233"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> For a royal investiture, therefore, the [States General of the Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_General_of_the_Netherlands "States General of the Netherlands") (the Dutch Parliament) meets for a ceremonial joint session in Amsterdam. The ceremony traditionally takes place at the [Nieuwe Kerk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nieuwe_Kerk_(Amsterdam) "Nieuwe Kerk (Amsterdam)") on [Dam Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_Square "Dam Square"), immediately after the former monarch has signed the act of abdication at the nearby [Royal Palace of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Amsterdam "Royal Palace of Amsterdam"). Normally, however, the Parliament sits in [The Hague](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hague "The Hague"), the city which has historically been the seat of the [Dutch government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_the_Netherlands "Politics of the Netherlands"), the [Dutch monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_Netherlands "Monarchy of the Netherlands"), and the [Dutch supreme court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Netherlands "Supreme Court of the Netherlands"). Foreign embassies are also located in The Hague.

### Symbols\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Symbols")\]

The coat of arms of Amsterdam is composed of several historical elements. First and centre are three [St Andrew's crosses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saltire "Saltire"), aligned in a vertical band on the city's shield (although Amsterdam's [patron saint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint") was [Saint Nicholas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Nicholas "Saint Nicholas")). These St Andrew's crosses can also be found on the city shields of neighbours [Amstelveen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amstelveen "Amstelveen") and [Ouder-Amstel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouder-Amstel "Ouder-Amstel"). This part of the coat of arms is the basis of the [flag of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Amsterdam "Flag of Amsterdam"), flown by the city government, but also as [civil ensign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_ensign "Civil ensign") for ships registered in Amsterdam. Second is the [Imperial Crown of Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_Crown_of_Austria "Imperial Crown of Austria"). In 1489, out of gratitude for services and loans, [Maximilian I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximilian_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor") awarded Amsterdam the right to adorn its coat of arms with the [king's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_of_the_Romans "King of the Romans") crown. Then, in 1508, this was replaced with Maximilian's [imperial crown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_crown "Imperial crown") when he was crowned [Holy Roman Emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor "Holy Roman Emperor"). In the early years of the 17th century, Maximilian's crown in Amsterdam's coat of arms was again replaced, this time with the crown of [Emperor Rudolph II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor"), a crown that became the Imperial [Crown of Austria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrian_Crown_Jewels "Austrian Crown Jewels"). The lions date from the late 16th century, when city and province became part of the [Republic of the Seven United Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_Republic "Dutch Republic"). Last came the city's official motto: _Heldhaftig, Vastberaden, Barmhartig_ ("Heroic, Determined, Merciful"), bestowed on the city in 1947 by [Queen Wilhelmina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelmina_of_the_Netherlands "Wilhelmina of the Netherlands"), in recognition of the city's bravery during the Second World War.

## Transport\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Transport")\]

### Metro, tram and bus\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Metro, tram and bus")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_-_Keizersgracht_-_1316.jpg)

A tram crossing the Keizersgracht

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg/220px-NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:NoordZuidLijn_Metrostation_Europaplein_hnapel_004.jpg)

Currently, there are sixteen [tram routes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trams_in_Amsterdam "Trams in Amsterdam") and five [metro routes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Metro "Amsterdam Metro"). All are operated by municipal public transport operator [Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemeentelijk_Vervoerbedrijf "Gemeentelijk Vervoerbedrijf") (GVB), which also runs the city bus network.

Four fare-free GVB ferries carry pedestrians and cyclists across the [IJ lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IJ_(Amsterdam) "IJ (Amsterdam)") to the [borough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boroughs_of_Amsterdam "Boroughs of Amsterdam") of [Amsterdam-Noord](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam-Noord "Amsterdam-Noord"), and two fare-charging ferries run east and west along the harbour. There are also privately operated water taxis, a water bus, a boat sharing operation, electric rental boats and canal cruises, that transport people along Amsterdam's waterways.

Regional buses, and some suburban buses, are operated by [Connexxion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connexxion "Connexxion") and [EBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egged_(company) "Egged (company)"). International coach services are provided by [Eurolines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurolines "Eurolines") from [Amsterdam Amstel railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station"), [IDBUS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IDBUS "IDBUS") from [Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Sloterdijk_railway_station "Amsterdam Sloterdijk railway station"), and [Megabus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megabus_(Europe) "Megabus (Europe)") from the Zuiderzeeweg in the east of the city.

In order to facilitate easier transport to the centre of Amsterdam, the city has various P+R Locations where people can park their car at an affordable price and transfer to one of the numerous public transport lines.<sup id="cite_ref-234"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup>

### Car\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Car")\]

Amsterdam was intended in 1932 to be the hub, a kind of [Kilometre Zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilometre_Zero "Kilometre Zero"), of the [highway system of the Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_motorways_in_the_Netherlands "List of motorways in the Netherlands"),<sup id="cite_ref-Autosnelweg_1930_235-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1930-235">[235]</a></sup> with freeways numbered One to Eight planned to originate from the city.<sup id="cite_ref-Autosnelweg_1930_235-1"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1930-235">[235]</a></sup> The outbreak of the Second World War and shifting priorities led to the current situation, where only roads [A1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A1_motorway_(Netherlands) "A1 motorway (Netherlands)"), [A2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A2_motorway_(Netherlands) "A2 motorway (Netherlands)"), and [A4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A4_motorway_(Netherlands) "A4 motorway (Netherlands)") originate from Amsterdam according to the original plan. The [A3](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=A3_motorway_(Netherlands)&action=edit&redlink=1 "A3 motorway (Netherlands) (page does not exist)") to [Rotterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam") was cancelled in 1970 in order to conserve the [Groene Hart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Groene_Hart "Groene Hart"). Road [A8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A8_motorway_(Netherlands) "A8 motorway (Netherlands)"), leading north to [Zaandam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaandam "Zaandam") and the [A10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A10_motorway_(Netherlands) "A10 motorway (Netherlands)") [Ringroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beltway "Beltway") were opened between 1968 and 1974.<sup id="cite_ref-Autosnelweg_1970_236-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Autosnelweg_1970-236">[236]</a></sup> Besides the A1, A2, A4 and A8, several freeways, such as the [A7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A7_motorway_(Netherlands) "A7 motorway (Netherlands)") and [A6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A6_motorway_(Netherlands) "A6 motorway (Netherlands)"), carry traffic mainly bound for Amsterdam.

The [A10 ringroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A10_motorway_(Netherlands) "A10 motorway (Netherlands)") surrounding the city connects Amsterdam with the Dutch [national network of freeways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_motorways_in_the_Netherlands "List of motorways in the Netherlands"). [Interchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interchange_(road) "Interchange (road)") on the A10 allow cars to enter the city by transferring to one of the 18 _city roads_, numbered S101 through to S118. These city roads are regional roads without [grade separation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grade_separation "Grade separation"), and sometimes without a [central reservation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_reservation "Central reservation"). Most are accessible by cyclists. The S100 _Centrumring_ is a smaller ringroad circumnavigating the city's centre.

In the city centre, driving a car is discouraged. Parking fees are expensive, and many streets are closed to cars or are [one-way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_traffic "One-way traffic").<sup id="cite_ref-Fiets_237-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Fiets-237">[237]</a></sup> The local government sponsors [carsharing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carsharing "Carsharing") and [carpooling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpool "Carpool") initiatives such as _Autodelen_ and _Meerijden.nu_.<sup id="cite_ref-cars_238-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-cars-238">[238]</a></sup> The local government has also started removing parking spaces in the city, with the goal of removing 10,000 spaces (roughly 1,500 per year) by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-239"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup>

### National rail\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: National rail")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg/250px-Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_Central_Station1.jpg)

Amsterdam is served by ten [stations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Railway_stations_in_the_Netherlands#A "Railway stations in the Netherlands") of the [Nederlandse Spoorwegen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nederlandse_Spoorwegen "Nederlandse Spoorwegen") (Dutch Railways).<sup id="cite_ref-Stationsweb_240-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Stationsweb-240">[240]</a></sup> Five are intercity stops: [Sloterdijk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sloterdijk_(Amsterdam) "Sloterdijk (Amsterdam)"), [Zuid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Zuid_railway_station "Amsterdam Zuid railway station"), [Amstel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Amstel_railway_station "Amsterdam Amstel railway station"), [Bijlmer ArenA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Bijlmer_ArenA_railway_station "Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station") and [Amsterdam Centraal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_railway_station "Amsterdam Centraal railway station"). The stations for local services are: [Lelylaan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Lelylaan_railway_station "Amsterdam Lelylaan railway station"), [RAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_RAI_railway_station "Amsterdam RAI railway station"), [Holendrecht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Holendrecht_railway_station "Amsterdam Holendrecht railway station"), [Muiderpoort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Muiderpoort_railway_station "Amsterdam Muiderpoort railway station") and [Science Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Science_Park_railway_station "Amsterdam Science Park railway station"). [Amsterdam Centraal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_railway_station "Amsterdam Centraal railway station") is also an international railway station. From the station there are regular services to destinations such as Austria, Belarus, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Poland, Russia, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. Among these trains are international trains of the [Nederlandse Spoorwegen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nederlandse_Spoorwegen "Nederlandse Spoorwegen") (Amsterdam-Berlin), the [Eurostar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") (Amsterdam-Brussels-London), [Thalys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalys "Thalys") (Amsterdam-Brussels-Paris/Lille), and [Intercity-Express](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intercity-Express "Intercity-Express") (Amsterdam–Cologne–Frankfurt).<sup id="cite_ref-241"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup>

### Airport\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Airport")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_%287325966610%29.jpg/220px-Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_%287325966610%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Schiphol_Airport_Pier_D_(7325966610).jpg)

[Amsterdam Airport Schiphol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Airport_Schiphol "Amsterdam Airport Schiphol") is less than 20 minutes by train from [Amsterdam Centraal station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_Centraal_station "Amsterdam Centraal station") and is served by domestic and international intercity trains, such as [Thalys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalys "Thalys"), [Eurostar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurostar "Eurostar") and Intercity Brussel. Schiphol is the largest airport in the Netherlands, the third-largest in Europe, and the 14th-largest in the world in terms of passengers. It handles over 68 million passengers per year and is the home base of four airlines, [KLM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KLM "KLM"), [Transavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transavia "Transavia"), [Martinair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martinair "Martinair") and [Arkefly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arkefly "Arkefly").<sup id="cite_ref-244"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> As of 2014, Schiphol was the fifth [busiest airport in the world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic "World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic") measured by international passenger numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-passengerrank_245-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-passengerrank-245">[245]</a></sup> This airport is 4 meters below sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-246"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> Although Schiphol is internationally known as Amsterdam Schiphol Airport it actually lies in the neighbouring municipality of Haarlemmermeer, southwest of the city.

### Cycling\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Cycling")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg/220px-Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amsterdam_-_Bicycles_-_1058.jpg)

Police bicyclist crossing a bridge over the Prinsengracht

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg/220px-Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bicyclist_at_Amsterdam.jpg)

Amsterdam is one of the most [bicycle-friendly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle-friendly "Bicycle-friendly") large cities in the world and is a centre of [bicycle culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle_culture "Bicycle culture") with good facilities for cyclists such as bike paths and [bike racks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle_stand "Bicycle stand"), and several guarded bike storage garages (_fietsenstalling_) which can be used.

According to the most recent figures published by Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), in 2015 the 442.693 households (850.000 residents) in Amsterdam together owned 847.000 bicycles – 1.91 bicycle per household.<sup id="cite_ref-247"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> Theft is widespread—in 2011, about 83,000 bicycles were stolen in Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-248"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> Bicycles are used by all socio-economic groups because of their convenience, Amsterdam's small size, the 400 km (249 mi) of bike paths,<sup id="cite_ref-249"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> the flat terrain, and the inconvenience of driving an automobile.<sup id="cite_ref-250"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>

## Education\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Education")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg/220px-Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Agnietenkapel_Gate.jpg)

Amsterdam has two universities: the [University of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Amsterdam "University of Amsterdam") (_Universiteit van Amsterdam_, UvA), and the _[Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vrije_Universiteit_Amsterdam "Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam")_ (VU). Other institutions for higher education include an art school – [Gerrit Rietveld Academie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerrit_Rietveld_Academie "Gerrit Rietveld Academie"), a [university of applied sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hogeschool "Hogeschool") – the [Hogeschool van Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hogeschool_van_Amsterdam "Hogeschool van Amsterdam"), and the [Amsterdamse Hogeschool voor de Kunsten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdamse_Hogeschool_voor_de_Kunsten "Amsterdamse Hogeschool voor de Kunsten"). Amsterdam's [International Institute of Social History](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Institute_of_Social_History "International Institute of Social History") is one of the world's largest documentary and research institutions concerning [social history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_history "Social history"), and especially the [history of the labour movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_history_(discipline) "Labor history (discipline)"). Amsterdam's [Hortus Botanicus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hortus_Botanicus_(Amsterdam) "Hortus Botanicus (Amsterdam)"), founded in the early 17th century, is one of the oldest botanical gardens in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-Hortus_251-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Hortus-251">[251]</a></sup> with many old and rare specimens, among them the [coffee plant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee "Coffee") that served as the parent for the entire [coffee culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_culture "Coffee culture") in Central and South America.<sup id="cite_ref-he_252-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-he-252">[252]</a></sup>

There are over 200 primary schools in Amsterdam.<sup id="cite_ref-253"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> Some of these primary schools base their teachings on particular pedagogic theories like the various [Montessori](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maria_Montessori "Maria Montessori") schools. The biggest Montessori high school in Amsterdam is the [Montessori Lyceum Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montessori_Lyceum_Amsterdam "Montessori Lyceum Amsterdam"). Many schools, however, are based on religion. This used to be primarily Roman Catholicism and various Protestant denominations, but with the influx of Muslim immigrants, there has been a rise in the number of Islamic schools. Jewish schools can be found in the southern suburbs of Amsterdam.

Amsterdam is noted for having five independent grammar schools (Dutch: gymnasia), the [Vossius Gymnasium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vossius_Gymnasium "Vossius Gymnasium"), [Barlaeus Gymnasium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barlaeus_Gymnasium "Barlaeus Gymnasium"), St. [Ignatius Gymnasium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignatius_Gymnasium "Ignatius Gymnasium"), [Het 4e Gymnasium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Het_4e_Gymnasium "Het 4e Gymnasium") and the Cygnus Gymnasium where a classical curriculum including [Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin "Latin") and [classical Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") is taught. Though believed until recently by many to be an anachronistic and elitist concept that would soon die out, the gymnasia have recently experienced a revival, leading to the formation of a fourth and fifth grammar school in which the three aforementioned schools participate. Most secondary schools in Amsterdam offer a variety of different levels of education in the same school. The city also has various colleges ranging from art and design to politics and economics which are mostly also available for students coming from other countries.

Schools for foreign nationals in Amsterdam include the [Amsterdam International Community School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam_International_Community_School "Amsterdam International Community School"), [British School of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_School_of_Amsterdam "British School of Amsterdam"), [Albert Einstein International School Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Einstein_International_School_Amsterdam "Albert Einstein International School Amsterdam"), [Lycée Vincent van Gogh La Haye-Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Vincent_van_Gogh_La_Haye-Amsterdam "Lycée Vincent van Gogh La Haye-Amsterdam") primary campus (French school), [International School of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_School_of_Amsterdam "International School of Amsterdam"), and the [Japanese School of Amsterdam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_School_of_Amsterdam "Japanese School of Amsterdam").

## Notable people\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Notable people")\]

## Media\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Media")\]

Amsterdam is a prominent centre for national and international media. Some locally based newspapers include _[Het Parool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Het_Parool "Het Parool")_, a national daily paper; _[De Telegraaf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Telegraaf "De Telegraaf")_, the largest Dutch daily newspaper; the daily newspapers _[Trouw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trouw "Trouw")_, _[de Volkskrant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Volkskrant "De Volkskrant")_ and _[NRC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NRC_(newspaper) "NRC (newspaper)")_; _[De Groene Amsterdammer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_Groene_Amsterdammer "De Groene Amsterdammer")_, a weekly newspaper; the free newspapers _[Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro_(Dutch_newspaper) "Metro (Dutch newspaper)")_ and _[The Holland Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Holland_Times "The Holland Times")_ (printed in English).

Amsterdam is home to the second-largest Dutch commercial TV group [SBS Broadcasting Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SBS_Broadcasting_Group "SBS Broadcasting Group"), consisting of TV-stations [SBS 6](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SBS_6 "SBS 6"), [Net 5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_5 "Net 5") and [Veronica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veronica_(TV_channel) "Veronica (TV channel)"). However, Amsterdam is not considered 'the media city of the Netherlands'. The town of [Hilversum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilversum "Hilversum"), 30 km (19 mi) south-east of Amsterdam, has been crowned with this unofficial title. Hilversum is the principal centre for radio and television broadcasting in the Netherlands. [Radio Netherlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Netherlands_Worldwide "Radio Netherlands Worldwide"), heard worldwide via shortwave radio since the 1920s, is also based there. Hilversum is home to an extensive complex of audio and television studios belonging to the national broadcast production company NOS, as well as to the studios and offices of all the Dutch public broadcasting organisations and many commercial TV production companies.

In 2012, the music video of Far East Movement, 'Live My Life', was filmed in various parts of Amsterdam.

Also, several movies were filmed in Amsterdam, such as [James Bond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Bond "James Bond")'s [Diamonds Are Forever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamonds_Are_Forever_(film) "Diamonds Are Forever (film)"), [Ocean's Twelve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocean%27s_Twelve "Ocean's Twelve"), [Girl with a Pearl Earring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Girl_with_a_Pearl_Earring_(film) "Girl with a Pearl Earring (film)") and [The Hitman's Bodyguard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hitman%27s_Bodyguard "The Hitman's Bodyguard"). Amsterdam is also featured in [John Green](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Green "John Green")'s book _[The Fault in Our Stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fault_in_Our_Stars "The Fault in Our Stars")_, which has been made into [a film](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fault_in_Our_Stars_(film) "The Fault in Our Stars (film)") as well that partly takes place in Amsterdam.

## Housing\[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Amsterdam&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Housing")\]

From the late 1960s onwards many buildings in Amsterdam have been [squatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squatting "Squatting") both for housing and for using as social centres.<sup id="cite_ref-Owens_254-0"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_note-Owens-254">[254]</a></sup> A number of these squats have legalised and become well known, such as [OCCII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OCCII "OCCII"), [OT301](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OT301 "OT301"), [Paradiso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradiso_(Amsterdam) "Paradiso (Amsterdam)") and [Vrankrijk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vrankrijk "Vrankrijk").

49.  **[^](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amsterdam#cite_ref-49 "Jump up")** A case in point is that after [his trial and sentencing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_affair "Galileo affair") in Rome in 1633, [Galileo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei") chose [Lodewijk Elzevir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lodewijk_Elzevir "Lodewijk Elzevir") in Amsterdam to publish one of his finest works, _[Two New Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two_New_Sciences "Two New Sciences")_. See Wade Rowland (2003), _Galileo's Mistake, A new look at the epic confrontation between Galileo and the Church_, New York: [Arcade Publishing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcade_Publishing "Arcade Publishing"), [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [1-55970-684-8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-55970-684-8 "Special:BookSources/1-55970-684-8"), p. 260.

-   Berns, Jan; Daan, Jo (1993). _Hij zeit wat: de Amsterdamse volkstaal_. The Hague: BZZTôH. [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-9062917563](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-9062917563 "Special:BookSources/978-9062917563").
-   Frijhoff, Willem; Prak, Maarten (2005), _Geschiedenis van Amsterdam. Zelfbewuste stadsstaat 1650–1813_, Amsterdam: SUN, [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-9058751386](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-9058751386 "Special:BookSources/978-9058751386")
-   Mak, Geert (1994), _Een kleine geschiedenis van Amsterdam_, Amsterdam & Antwerp: Atlas, [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-9045019536](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-9045019536 "Special:BookSources/978-9045019536")
-   Charles Caspers & Peter Jan Margry (2017), _Het Mirakel van Amsterdam. Biografie van een betwiste devotie_ (Amsterdam, Prometheus).
-   Nusteling, Hubert (1985), _Welvaart en werkgelegenheid in Amsterdam 1540–1860. Een relaas over demografie, economie en sociale politiek van een wereldstad_, Amsterdam: De Bataafsche Leeuw, [ISBN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-9067070829](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-9067070829 "Special:BookSources/978-9067070829")
-   Ramaer, J.C. (1921), "Middelpunten der bewoning in Nederland, voorheen en thans", _TAG 2e Serie_, vol. 38
-   Van Dillen, J.G. (1929), _Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven en het gildewezen van Amsterdam_, The Hague
-   Van Leeuwen, M.; Oeppen, J.E. (1993), "Reconstructing the Demographic Regime of Amsterdam 1681–1920", _Economic and Social History in the Netherlands_, vol. 5, pp. 61–102, [hdl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hdl_(identifier) "Hdl (identifier)"):[10622/09251669-1993-001](https://hdl.handle.net/10622%2F09251669-1993-001)
